Award.AwardTitle: CSR: Small: System Research to Advance Real-time Dust Storm Forecasting

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project anticipates significantly speeding up prediction of dust storms. The PIs have successful preliminary work in the area in collaboration with relevant domain experts at federal agencies such as NOAA and FEMA.

The major challenges in this project are geospatial interoperability and format heterogeneity across data sources. The PIs speed up collection of high-volume continuous sensor data, run dust-storm prediction models, and disseminate detailed prediction data to users such as emergency managers. The approach to speeding-up the first task is based on reduction of data via data differencing. Challenges in choice of data differencing schemes include client-server load-balancing, diversity of geospatial data types (e.g. raster, vector), and possibility of errors/missing data in some snapshots, which may be magnified via difference techniques leading to errors in dust forecast. Speed up for prediction models is done by customizing caching and computation job scheduling to dust prediction models. For example, a location?s potential dust storm is predicted from properties of nearby places based on wind direction etc. To speed-up result dissemination, the project studies geospatial data access patterns and develops custom pre-fetching techniques to be able to serve a large number of concurrent users.

The results of this project will benefit society by improving forecasting of dust storms. Custom techniques for data difference, caching, job-scheduling and pre-fetching may also benefit other societal applications such as weather prediction. It will also lead to curriculum development as well as training of graduate and undergraduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Dust storms are an increasingly frequent and severe natural hazard. Dust storms can trigger significant and immediate socioeconomic and environmental impacts. To respond to such a natural hazard, a real-time and high-resolution dust storm forecasting system is imperative. However, real-time and high-resolution dust storm forecasting demands fast data processing of huge amounts of geospatial data obtained from geographically distributed data sources nationwide in real time. That is, such a system needs to perform geospatial computing and analyses to get real-time information as fast as possible. Unfortunately, existing geospatial information systems cannot provide dust storm forecasting in desired resolution in real time.

 

The research supported by this award has mainly concerned on how to improve the dust forecasting response time and resolution. For this purpose, we have investigated different prospective of the problem, ranging from the dust storm models, to the cloud computing support, domain decomposition, as well as parallel processing optimization and scheduling algorithms.  For example, we studied how to incorporate new dynamic input, such as soil moisture and greenness vegetation fraction, to improve the accuracy and resolution of the dust storm forecasting model. We have also extensively and experimentally evaluated the effectiveness and challenges of different open source cloud software in supporting the dust storm simulations.  To derive valuable and intuitive information from dust storm simulations, we have developed a multi-threshold region-growing based algorithm to identify critical dust storm features from 3D dust storm simulations. In order to track dust storm events, we have also designed a spatiotemporal data model to facilitate the storage and organization of 4D simulation data, to allow better representation and analysis of dust storm events of interest.

 

These techniques developed through this project are not only applicable to the dust storm simulations, but also helpful in studying other natural hazards, such as weather forecasting. The approaches we have followed to abstract the challenges and the methodology we proposed are both potentially useful in other fields. The research supported by this award has also produced about 15 peer-reviewed papers published at various journals, conferences, and workshops. We have also presented our results in various occasions, including the International conferences and workshops where our papers were published. Some of our research outcomes have also been included in the class teaching.

 

Several Ph.D. students who have participated in the research of this project have graduated. Among them, one student, a female, has started as a tenure-track assistant professor in University of Wisconsin-Madison.  Another student, who was mainly supported by this award, has also defended his dissertation and joined University of South Carolina as a tenure-track assistant professor in 2015. Two other Ph.D. students, who were mainly supported by this award, have joined industry as research and development engineers.  Three other partially involved students are making good progress towards their Ph.D., and one is expected to graduate soon. They all have gained invaluable research experience from participating in this project.
